sp.p: (But in Hell, Sir)

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: His Chayres bee alwayes empty, his Sciſſors ruſt, and his Combes mould in their Caſes.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Very dreadfull that! (And may he looſe the inuention, Sir, of caruing Lanternes in Paper)

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Let there bee no Baud carted that yeere, to employ a Baſon of his: but let him be glad to eate his Sponge, for Bread.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: And drinke lotium to it, and much good doe him.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Or, for want of Bread—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Eate Eare-Waxe, Sir. I'll helpe you. Or draw'his owne Teeth, and adde them to the Lute-ſtring.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No, beate the olde ones to poulder, and make Bread of them.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: (Yes, make meale o' the Milſtones.)

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: May all the Botches, and Burnes, that he has cur'd on others, breake out vpon him.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: And he now forget the cure of 'hem in himſelfe, Sir: or, if hee doe remember it, let him ha' ſcrap'd all his Linnen into Lint for't, and haue not a ragge left him, to ſet vp with.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: That falls out often, Madame, that hee that thinkes himſelfe the Maſter-wit, is the Maſter-foole. I aſſure your Ladiſhip, ye cannot laugh at her.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: No, wee'll haue her to the Colledge: and ſhe haue wit, ſhe ſhall be one of vs.! ſhall ſhee not Centaure? wee'll make her a Collegiate.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: Yes faith, Madame, and Mauis, and ſhee will ſet vp a ſide.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Beleeue it Madame, and Miſtris Mauis, ſhee will ſuſtaine her part.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: I'll tell you that, when I haue talk'd with her, and try'd her.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Ʋſe her very ciuilly, Mauis.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: So I will, Madame.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Bleſſed minute, that they would whiſper thus euer.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: In the the meane time, Madame, would but your Ladiſhip helpe to vexe him a little: you know his diſeaſe, talke to him about the Wedding Ceremonies, or call for your Gloues, or—

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Let me alone. Centaure, helpe mee. Maſter Bride-groome, where are you?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O, it was too miraculouſly good to laſt!

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: We ſee no Enſignes of a Wedding, here; no Character of a Brideale: where be our Skarfes, and our Gloues? I pray you, giue 'hem vs. Let's know your Brides Colours, and yours, at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: Alas, Madame, he has prouided none.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Had I knowne your Ladiſhips Painter, I would.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p:
He has giuen it you, Centaure, yfaith. But doe you heare Maſter Moroſe, a Ieſt will not abſolue you in this manner. You that haue ſuck'd the Milke of the Court, and from thence haue beene brought vp to the very ſtrong meates, and Wine, of it; beene a Courtier from the Biggen, to the Night-Cap: (as wee may ſay) and you, to offend in ſuch a high point of Ceremonie, as this and let your Nuptialls
want all markes of ſolemnitie! How much Plate haue you loſt to day (if you had but regarded your profit) what gifts, what friends, through your meere Ruſticitie?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Madame—

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Pardon me, Sir, I muſt inſinuate your errors to you. No Gloues? no Garters? no Skarfes? no Epithalamium? no Maſque?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Yes, Madame, I'll make an Epithalamium, I promis'd my Miſtris, I haue begunne it already: will your Ladiſhip heare it?

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: I, good Iack Daw.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Will it pleaſe your Ladiſhip command a Chamber, and bee priuate with hour friend? you ſhall haue your choice of Roomes, to retyre to after: my whole Houſe is yours. I know, it hath beene your Ladiſhis errand, into the Citie, at other times, how euer now you haue beene vnhappily diuerted vpon mee▪ but I ſhall bee loth to breake any honorable cuſtome of your Ladiſhips. And therefore, good Madame—

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Come, you are a rude Bride-groome, to entertayne Ladies of honour in this faſhion.

sp.speaker: Cer.
sp.p: He is a rude Groome, indeed.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: By that light, you deſerue to grafted, and haue your Hornes reach from one ſide of the Iland, to the other. Doe not miſtake mee, Sir, I but ſpeake this, to giue the Ladies ſome heart againe, not for any malice to you.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Is this your Brau • , Ladies?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: As God helpe mee, if you vtter ſuch another word, I'll take Miſtris Bride in and begin to you, in a very ſad cup, doe you ſee? Goe too, know your friends, and ſuch, as loue you.

div.head: Act III. Scene VII.
div.stage: Clerimont, Moroſe, Tru-wit, Dauphine, La-Foole, Otter, Mrs. Otter, &c.

sp.p: BY your leaue, Ladies. Doe you want any Muſique? I haue brought you varietie of noyſes. Play, Sirs, all of you.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Muſique of all ſorts. O, a plot, a plot, a plot, a plot vpon me! This day, I ſhall bee their Anuile to worke on, they will grate mee aſunder. 'Tis worſe then the noyſe of a Saw.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: No, they are Haire, Roſin, and Guts. I can giue you the Receipt.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Peace, Boyes.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Play, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Peace, Raſcals. You ſee who's your friend now, Sir? Take courage, put on a Martyrs reſolution. Mocke downe all their attemptings, with patience. 'Tis but a day, and I would ſuffer heroically. Should an Aſſe exceed mee in fortitude? No. You betray your infirmitie with your hanging dull eares, and make them inſult: beare vp brauely, and conſtantly. Looke you here, Sir, what honour is done you vnexpected, La-Foole paſſes ouer ſewing the • eate. by your Nephew; a Wedding Dinner come, and a Knight Sewer before it, for the more reputation: and fine Miſtris Otter, your Neighbour, in the Rump, or Tayle of it.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Is that Gorgon, that Meduſa come? Hide mee, hide me.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: I warrant you, Sir, ſhee will not transforme you. Looke vpon her with a good courage. Pray you entertayne her, and conduct your Gueſts in, No? Miſtris Bride, will you entreat in the Ladies? your Bridegroome is ſo ſhame-fac'd, here—

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Will it pleaſe your Ladiſhip, Madame?

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: With the benefit of your companie, Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Seruant, pray you performe your duties.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: And glad to be commanded, Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: How like you her wit, Mauis.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: Very prettily, abſolutely well.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: 'Tis my place.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: You ſhall pardon me, Miſtris Otter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: Why, I am a Collegiate.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: But not in ordinary.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: But I am.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: Wee'll diſpute that within.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Would this had laſted a little longer.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: And that they had ſent for the Heralds. Captayne Otter, what newes?

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: I haue brought my Bull, Beare, and Horſe, in priuate, and yonder are the Trumpetters without, and the Drum, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O, ô, ô. The Drum, and Trumpets ſound,

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: And we will haue a rouſe in each of 'hem, anon, for bold Britons, yfaith.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Follow, follow, follow.
WAs there euer poore Bride-groome ſo tormented? or man indeed?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I haue not read of the like, in the Chronicles of the Land.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Sure, he cannot but goe to a place of reſt, after all this Purgatorie.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: He may preſume it, I thinke.

sp.speaker: Tru
sp.p:
The ſpitting, the coughing, the laughter, the neeſing, the farting, dauncing, noyſe of the Muſique, and her maſculine, and lowd commanding, and vrging the whole
Family, makes him thinke he has marryed a Furie.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: And ſhe carries it vp brauely.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: I, ſhe takes any occaſion to ſpeake: that's the height on't.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: And how ſo berly Dauphine labours to ſatisfie him, that it was none of his plot!

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: And has almoſt brought him to the faith, i' the article. Here he comes. Where is he now? what's become of him, Dauphine?

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: O, hold me vp a little, I ſhall goe away i' the ieſt elſe. Hee has got on his whole Neſt of Night-caps, and lock'd himſelfe vp, i' the top o' the Houſe, as high as euer he can climbe from the noyſe. I peep'd in at a cranny, and ſaw him ſitting ouer a croſſe-beame o' the roofe, like him o' the Sadiers Horſe in Fleetstreet, vp-right: and hee will ſleepe there.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: But where are your Collegiates?

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: With-drawne with the Bride in priuate.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: O, they are inſtructing her i' the Colledge-Grammar. If ſhee haue grace with them, ſhee knowes all their ſecrets inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Mee thinkes, the Lady Haughty lookes well to day, for all my diſprayſe of her i' the morning. I thinke, I ſhall come about to thee againe, Tru-wit.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Beleeue it, I told you right. Women ought to repayre the loſſes, time and yeeres haue made i' their features, with dreſſings. And an intelligent Woman, if ſhee know by her ſelfe the leaſt defect, will bee moſt curious, to hide it: and it becomes her. If ſhee bee ſhort, let her ſit much, leſt when ſhe ſtands, ſhe be thought to ſit. If ſhe haue an ill foot, let her weare her Gowne the longer, and her Shoo the thinner. If a fat Hand, and ſcald Nailes, let her carue the leſſe, and act in Gloues. If a ſowre breath, let her neuer diſcourſe faſting: and alwayes talke at her diſtance. If ſhe haue black and rugged Teeth, let her offer the leſſe at laughter, eſpecially if ſhe laugh wide, and open.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: O, you ſhall haue ſome women, when they laugh, you would thinke they bray'd, it is ſo rude, and—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: I, and others, that will ſtalke i'their gait like an Eſtrich, and take huge ſtrides. I cannot endure ſuch a ſight. I loue meaſure i' the feet, and number i' the voyce: they are Gentleneſſes, thaa oft-times draw no leſſe then the face.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: How cam'ſt thou to ſtudie theſe Creatures ſo exactly? I would thou would'ſt make me a Proficient.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Yes, but you muſt leaue to liue i' your Chamber then a month together vpon Amadis de Gaule, or Don Quixote, as you are wont; and come abroad where the matter is frequent, to Court, to Tiltings, publique Showes, and Feaſts, to Playes, and Church ſometimes: thither they come to ſhew their new Tyres too, to ſee, and to be ſeene. In theſe places a m • n ſhall find whome to loue, whome to play with, whome to touch once, whom to hold cuer. The varietie arreſts his iudgement. A Wench to pleaſe a man comes not downe dropping from the ſeeling, as hee lyes on his backe droning a Tobacco Pipe. He muſt goe where ſhe is.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Yes, and be neuer the neere.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Out Heretique. That diffidence makes thee worthy, it ſhould be ſo.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: He ſayes true to you, Dauphine.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: A man ſhould not doubt to ouer come any Woman. Thinke hee can vanquiſh 'hem, and he ſhall, for though they denie, their deſire is to bee tempted. Penelope her ſelfe cannot hold out long. Oſtend, you ſaw, was taken at laſt. You muſt perſeuer, and hold to your purpoſe. They would ſollicite vs, but that they are afraid. Howſoeuer, they wiſh in their hearts wee ſhould ſollicite them. Prayſe • hem, flatter. 'hem, you ſhall neuer want Eloquence, or truſt: euen the chaſteſt delight to feele themſelues that way rub'd. With Prayſes you muſt mixe Kiſſes too. If they take them, they'll take more. Though they ſtriue, they would bee ouercome.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: O, but a man muſt beware of force.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: It is to them an acceptable violence, and has ofttimes the place of the greateſt courteſie. Shee that might haue beene forc'd, and you let her goe free without touching though ſhe then ſeeme to thanke you, will euer hate you after: and glad i' the face, is aſſuredly ſad at the heart.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: But all women are not to be taken alwayes.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p:
'Tis true. No more then all Birds, or all Fiſhes. If you appeare learned to an ignorant Wench, or iocund to a ſad, or witty to a fooliſh, why ſhee preſently beginnes to miſtruſt herſelfe. You muſt approch them i' their owne height, their owne line: for the contrary makes many that feare to commit themſelues to noble and worthy fellowes, runne into the imbraces of a Raſcall. If ſhe loue Wit, giue Verſes, though you borrow 'hem of a friend, or buy 'hem, to haue good. If Valour, talke of your Sword, and be frequent in the mention of Quarrels, though you be ſtaunch in fighting. If actiuity be ſeen o'your Barbary often, or leaping ouer ſtooles, for the credit of your back. If ſhe loue good clothes or dreſſing haue your learned Counſel about you euery morning, your French Taylor, Barber, Linnener, &c. Let your Poulder, your Glaſſe, and your Combe, be your deareſt acquaintance. Take more care for the ornament of your head, then the ſafetie: and wiſh the Common-wealth rather troubled, then a haire about you. That will take her. Then if ſhee bee couetous and crauing, doe you promiſe any thing, and performe ſparingly: ſo ſhall you keepe her in appetite ſtill. Seeme as you would giue, but be like a barren field that yeelds little, or vnlucky Dice, to fooliſh, and hoping Gameſters. Let your gifts be flight, and daintie, ra her then precious. Let cunning be aboue coſt. Giue Cherries at time of yeere, or Apricots; and ſay they were ſent you out of the Countrey, though you bought 'hem in Cheap-ſiae. Admire her Tyres; like her in all faſhions; compare her in euery habit to ſome Deitie; inuent excellent Dreames to flatter her, and Riddles; or, if ſhee bee a great one, performe alwayes the ſecond
parts to her: like what ſhe likes, prayſe whom ſhee prayſes, and faile not to make the Houſhold and Seruants yours, yea the whole Family, and ſalute 'hem by their names: ('tis but light coſt if you can purchaſe' hem ſo) and make her Phyſician your Penſioner, and her chiefe woman. Nor will it bee out of your gaine to make loue to her too, ſo ſhe follow, not vſher, her Ladies pleaſure. All blabbing is taken away, when ſhe comes to be a part of the crime.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: On what Courtly lap haſt thou late ſlept, to come forth ſo ſudden and abſolute a Courtling?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Good faith, I ſhould rather queſtion you, that are ſo harkening after theſe Myſteries. I begin to ſuſpect your diligence, Dauphine. Speake, art thou in loue in earneſt?

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Yes by my troth am I: 'twere ill diſſembling before thee.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: With which of 'hem, I pray thee?

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: With all the Collegiates.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Out on thee. Wee'll keepe you at home, beleeue it, i' the Stable, and you be ſuch a Stallion.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: No, I like him well. Men ſhould loue wiſely, and all women: ſomeone for the face, and let her pleaſe the eye; another for the skin, and let her pleaſe the touch; a third for the voyce, and let her pleaſe the eare; and where the Obiects mixe, let the ſenſes ſo too. Thou wouldſt thinke it ſtrange, if I ſhould make 'hem all in loue with thee a fore Night!

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: I would ſay thou had'ſt the beſt Philtre i' the World, and couldſt doe more then Madame Medea, or Doctor Foreman.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: If I doe not, let me play the Mounte-banke for my meate while I liue, and the Bawd for my drinke.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: So be it, I ſay.

div.head: Act IIII. Scene II.
div.stage: Otter, Clerimont, Daw, Dauphine, Moroſe, Tru-wit, La-Foole, Mrs. Otter.

sp.p: O Lord, Gentlemen, how my Knights and I haue miſt you here!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Why, Captaine, what Seruice? what Seruice?

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: To ſee mee bring vp my Bull, Beare, and Horſe to fight.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Yes faith, the Captaine ſayes we ſhall be his Dogs to bait 'hem.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: A good imployment.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Come on, let's ſee a courſe then.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: I am afraid my Couſin will bee offended if ſhee come.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Be afraid of nothing. Gentlemen, I haue plac'd the Drumme and the Trumpets, and one to giue 'hem the ſigne when you are readie. Here's my Bull for my ſelfe, and my Beare for Sir Iohn Daw, and my Horſe for Sir Amorous. Now ſet your foot to mine, and yours to his, and—

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: Pray God my Couſin come not.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Saint George, and Saint Andrew, feare no Couſins. Come, ſound, ſound. Et rauco ſtrepuerunt cornuacantu.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Well ſaid, Captaine, yfaith: well fought at the Bull.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Well held at the Beare.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Low, low, Captaine.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: O' the Horſe has kickt off his Dogge alreadie.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: I cannot drinke it, as I am a Knight.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Gods ſo, off with his Spurres, ſome-body.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: It goes againe my conſcience. My Couſin will be angry with it.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: I ha' done mine.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: You fought high and faire, Sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: At the head.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Like an excellent Beare-Dogge.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: You take no notice of the buſineſſe I hope.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Not a word, Sir, you ſee we are iouiall.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Sir Amorous, you muſt not aequiuocate. It muſt bee pull'd downe, for all my Couſin.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Sfoot, if you take not your drinke, they'll thinke you are diſcontented with ſome thing: you'll betray all, if you take the leaſt notice.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: Not I, I'll both drinke, and talke then.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: You muſt pull the Horſe on his knees, Sir Amorous: feare no Couſins. Iacta est alea.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: O, now hee's in his vaine, and bold. The leaſt hint giuen him of his Wife now will make him raile deſperately.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Speake to him of her.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Doe you, and I'll fetch her to the hearing of it.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Captaine hee-Otter, your ſhee-Otter is comming, your Wife.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Wife! Buz. Titinilitium. There's no ſuch thing in nature. I confeſſe, Gentlemen, I haue a Cooke, a Laundreſſe, a Houſe-Drudge, that ſerues my neceſſary turnes, and goes vnder that title: But hee's an Aſſe that will bee ſo vxorious, to tye his affections to one Circle. Come, the name duls appetite. Here, repleniſh againe: another bout. Wiues are naſty, ſluttiſh Animalls.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: O, Captaine.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: As euer the Earth bare, tribus verbis. Where's Maſter Tru-wit?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Hee's ſlipt aſide, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: But you muſt drinke, and be iouiall,

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Yes, giue it me.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: And me, too.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Let's be iouiall.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: As iouiall as you will.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p:
Agreed. Now you ſhall ha' the Beare, Couſin, and Sir Iohn Daw the Horſe, and I'll ha' the Bull ſtill. Sound
Tritons o' the Thames. Nunc eſt bibe • dum, nunc pede libero—

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Moroſe ſpeakes from aboue: the Trumpets ſounding. Villaines, Murderers, Sonnes of the Earth, and Traytors, what doe you there?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: O, now the Trumpets haue wak'd him, wee ſhall haue his company.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: A Wife is a ſciruy Clogdogdo; an vnlucky thing, a very fore-ſaid Beare-whelpe, without any good faſhion or breeding: mala bestia.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Why did you marry one then, Captaine?

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: His Wife is brought out to beare him. A poxe—I marryed with ſixe thouſand pound, I. I was in loue with that. I ha' not kiſt my Furie theſe fortie weekes.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: The more to blame you, Captaine.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Nay, Miſtris Otter, heare him a little firſt.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Shee has a breath worſe then my Grand-mothers, profecto.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: O trecherous Lyar. Kiſſe mee ſweete Maſter Tru-wit, and proue him a ſlandring Knaue.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: I'll rather beleeue you, Lady.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: And ſhee has a Perruke, that's like a pound of Hempe, made vp in Shoo-thrids.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: O Viper, Mandrake!

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: A moſt vile face! and yet ſhe ſpends me fortie pound a yeere in Mercurie, and Hogs-bones. All her Teeth were made i'the Blacke-Friers: both her eye-browes i'the Strand, and her Haire in Siuer-ſtreet. Euery part o' the Towne ownes a piece of her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: I cannot hold.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Shee takes her ſelfe aſunder ſtill when ſhee goes to bed, into ſome twentie Boxes; and about next day noone is put together againe, like a great Germane Clocke: and ſo comes forth and rings a tedious larum to the whole Houſe, and then is quiet againe for an houre, but for her quarters. Ha' you done me right, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: No, Sir, I'll doe you right with my quarters, with my quarters.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Shee falls vpon him and beats vpon him, O, hold, good Princeſſe.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Sound, ſound.
A battell, a battell.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: You notorious ſtinkardly Beareward, do's my breath ſmell?

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Vnder correction, deare Princeſſe: looke to my Beare, and my Horſe, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: Doe I want Teeth, and Eye-browes, thou Bul-Dogge?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Sound, ſound ſtill.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: No, I proteſt, vnder correction—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ott.
sp.p: I, now you are vnder correction, you proteſt: but you did not proteſt before correction, Sir. Thou Iudas, to offer to betray thy Princeſſe! I'll make thee an example—

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Moroſe deſcends with a longſword I will haue no ſuch examples in my Houſe, Lady Otter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: Ah—

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Mistris Mary Ambree, your examples are dangerous. Rogues, Hell-hounds, Stentors, out of my doores, you ſonnes of noyſe and tumult, begot on an ill May-day, or when the Gally-foiſt is a-float to Weſtminſter! A Trumpetter could not be conceiu'd but then!

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: What ailes you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: They haue rent my Roofe, Walles, and all my Windores aſunder, with their brazen throates.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Beſt follow him, Dauphine.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: So I will.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Where's Daw, and La-Foole?

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: They are both runne away, Sir. Good Gentlemen, helpe to pacifie my Princeſſe, and ſpeake to the great Ladies for mee. Now muſt I goe lye with the Beares this fortnight, and keepe out o' the way, till my peace bee made, for this ſcandale ſhee has taken. Did you not ſee my Bull-head, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Is't not on, Captaine?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: No: but hee may make a new one, by that, is on.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: O, here 'tis. And you come ouer, Gentlemen, and aske for Tom Otter, wee'll goe downe to Ratcliffe, and haue a courſe yfaith: for all theſe diſaſters. There's bona ſpet left.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Away, Captaine, get off while you are well.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I am glad we are rid of him.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: You had neuer beene, vnleſſe wee had put his Wife vpon him. His humour is as tedious at laſt, as it was ridiculous at firſt.

div.head: Act IIII. Scene III.
div.stage: Haughty, Miſtris Otter, Mauis, Daw, La-Foole, Cenraure, Epicoene, Tru-wit, Clerimont.

sp.p: WE wondred why you ſhreek'd ſo, Miſtris Otter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: O God, Madame, hee came downe with a huge long naked Weapon in both his hands, and look'd ſo dreadfully! Sure, hee's beſide himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: Why, what made you there, Miſtris Otter?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: Alas, Miſtris Mauis, I was chaſtiſing my ſubiect, and thought nothing of him.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Faith, Miſtris, you muſt doe ſo too. Learne to chaſtize. Miſtris Otter corrects her Husband ſo, hee dares not ſpeake, but vnder correction.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: And with his Hat off to her: 'twould doe you good to ſee.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: In ſadneſſe 'tis good, and mature counſell: practize it, Moroſe. I'll call you Moroſe ſtill now, as I call Centaure, and Mauis: we foure will be all one.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: And you'll come to the Colledge, and liue with vs?

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Make him giue Milke, and Honey.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: Looke how you manago him at firſt, you ſhall haue him euer after.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p:
Let him allow you your Coach, and foure Horſes,
your Woman, your Chamber-maid, your Page your Gentleman-Vſher, your French Cooke, and foure Groomes.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: And goe with vs, to Bed'lem, to the China Houſes, and to the Exchange.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: It will open the gate to your fame.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Here's Centaure has immortaliz'd her ſelfe, with taming of her wilde Male.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: I, ſhee has done the Miracle of the Kingdome.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: But Ladies, doe you count it lawfull to haue ſuch pluralitie of Seruants, and doe 'hem all graces?

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Why not? why ſhould women denie their Fauours to men? Are they the poorer, or the worſe?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Is the Thames the leſſe for the Dyers Water, Miſtris?

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: Or a Torch, for lighting many Torches?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Well ſaid, La-Foole; what a new one hee has got!

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: They are emptie loſſes, women feare, in this kind.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Beſides, Ladies ſhould bee mindfull of the approch of age, and let no time want his due vſe. The beſt of our dayes paſſe firſt.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: We are Riuers, that cannot bee call'd backe, Madame: ſhee that now excludes her Louers, may liue to lye a forſaken Beldame, in a frozen Bed.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: 'Tis true, Mauis: and who will wait on vs to coach then? or write, or tell vs the newes then? Make Anagrams of our names, and inuite vs to the Cock-pit, and kiſſe our hands all the Play-time, and draw their weapons for our honours?

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Not one.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Nay, my Miſtris is not altogether vn-intelligent of theſe things; here bee in preſence haue taſted of her fauours.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: What a neighing Hobby-horſe is this!

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: But not with intent to boaſt 'hem againe, Seruant. And haue you thoſe excellent Receits, Madame, to keepe your ſelues from bearing of Children?

div.p: now to comfort a poore Gentlewoman? Ay me! what fortune had I to marrie a diſtracted man?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: I'll tell you, Miſtris—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: How rarely ſhee holds it vp!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What meane you, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: What will you tell me, Seruant?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: The Diſeaſe in Greeke, is called Mayia, in Latine, Inſania, Furor, vel Ecſtaſis melancholica, that is, Egreſſio, when a man ex melancholico, euadit fanaticus.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Shall I haue a Lecture read vpon me aliue?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: But he may be but Phreneticus, yet, Miſtris? and Phrenetis is only delirium, or ſo—

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I, that is for the Diſeaſe, Seruant: but what is this to the cure? we are ſure enough of the Diſeaſe.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Let me goe.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Why, wee'll intreat her to hold her peace, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O, no. Labour not to ſtop her. Shee is like a Conduit-pipe, that will guſh out with more force, when ſhee opens againe.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: I'll tell you, Moroſe, you muſt talke Diuinitie to her altogether, or morall Philoſophy.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: I, and there's an excellent Booke of morall Philoſophy, Madame, of Raynard the Foxe, and all the Beaſts, call'd Dones Philoſophy.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: There is, indeed, Sir Amorous La-Foole.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O miſery!

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: I haue read it, my Lady Centaure, all ouer to my Couſin, hers.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: I, and 'tis a very good Booke as any is, of the Modernes.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Tut, he muſt haue Seneca read to him, and Plutarch, and the Ancients; the Modernes are not for this Diſeaſe.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Why, you diſcommended them too, to day, Sir Iohn

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: I, in ſome Caſes: but in theſe they are beſt, and Ariſtotles Ethicks.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: Say you ſo, Sir Iohn? I thinke you are decelu'd: you tooke it vpon truſt.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Where's Trusty, my woman? I'll end this difference. I pr'y thee, Otter, call her. Her Father and Mother were both mad, when they put her to mee.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I thinke ſo. Nay, Gentlemen, I am tame. This is but an exerciſe, I know a Marriage Ceremonie, which I muſt endure.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: And one of 'hem (I know not which) was cur'd with the Sick-mans Salue; and the other with Greens Groats-worth of wit.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: A very cheape Cure, Madame.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: I, it's very faeſible.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: My Lady call'd for you, Miſtris Truſty: you muſt decide a Controuerſie.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: O Truſty, which was it you ſaid, your Father, or your Mother, that was cur'd with the Sick-mans Salue?

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: My Mother, Madame, with the Salue.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Then it was the Sick-womans Salue.

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: And my Father with the Groats-worth of wit. But there was other meanes vs'd: we had a Preacher that would preach folke aſleepe ſtill; and ſo they were preſcrib'd to goe to Church, by an old Woman that was their Phyſician, thriſe a Weeke—

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: To ſleepe?

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: Yes forſooth: and euery night they reade themſelues aſleepe on thoſe Bookes.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Good faith, it ſtands with great reaſon. I would I knew where to procure thoſe Bookes.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Oh.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: I can helpe you with one of 'hem, Miſtris Moroſe, the Groats-worth of wit.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: But I ſhall disfurniſh you, Sir Amorous: can you ſpare it?

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: O, yes, for a Weeke, or ſo; I'll reade it my ſelfe to him.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: No, I muſt doe that, Sir: that muſt be my office.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Sure, hee would doe well inough, if hee could ſleepe.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No, I ſhould doe well inough, if you could ſleepe. Haue I no friend that will make her drunke? or giue her a little ladanum? or opium?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Why, Sir, ſhee talkes tenne times worſe in her ſleepe.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Doe you not know that, Sir? neuer ceaſes all night.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: And ſnores like a Porcpiſce.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O, redeeme me, Fate, redeeme me, Fate. For how how many cauſes may a man be diuorc'd, Nephew?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: I know not truly, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Some Diuine muſt reſolue you in that, Sir, or Canon Lawyer.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I will not reſt, I will not thinke of any other hope or comfort till I know.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Alas, poore man.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: You'll make him mad indeed, Ladies, if you purſue this.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: No, wee'll let him breathe, now a quarter of an houre, or ſo.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: By my faith, a large Truce.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Is that his keeper, that is gone with him?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: It is his Nephew, Madame.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: Sir Dauphine, Eugenie.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: He lookes like a very pittifull Knight—

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: As can bee. This Marriage, has put him out of all.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: He has not a penny in his Purſe, Madame—

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: He is ready to cry all this day.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: A very Sharke, hee ſet me i'the nicke t'other night at Primero.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: How theſe Swabbers talke!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I, Otters Wine has ſwell'd their humours aboue a Spring-tide.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Good Moroſe, let's goe in againe. I like your couches exceeding well: wee'll goe lie, and talke there.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I wait on you, Madame.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: 'Slight, I will haue 'hem as ſilent as Signes, and their Poſts too, e're I ha' done. Doe you heare, Ladie-Bride? I pray thee now, as thou art a noble Wench, continue this Diſcourſe of Dauphine within: but prayſe him exceedingly. Magnifie him with all the height of affection thou canſt. (I haue ſome purpoſe in't) and but beate off theſe two Rookes, Iack Daw, and his fellow, with any diſcontentment hether, and I'll honour thee for euer.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I was about it, here. It angred me to the ſoule, to heare 'hem beginne to talke ſo malepert.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Pray thee performe it, and thou win'ſt mee an Idolater to thee, euerlaſting.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Will you goe in, and heare me doe it?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: No, I'll ſtay heere. Driue 'hem out of your companie, 'tis all I aske: which cannot bee any way better done, then by extolling Dauphine, whome they haue ſo ſlighted.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I warrant you: you ſhall expect one of 'hem preſently.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: What a caſt of Kaſtrils are theſe, to hawke after Ladies, thus?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: I, and ſtrike at ſuch an Eagle as Dauphine.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Hee will bee madde, when wee will tell him. Here he comes.
O Sir, you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Where's thine Vncle?

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Runne out o'doores in's Night-caps, to talke with a Caſuiſt, about his Diuorce. It workes admirably.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Thou would'ſt ha' ſaid ſo, and thou had'ſt been here! The Ladies haue laught at thee, moſt Comically, ſince thou wentſt, Dauphine.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: And askt, if thou wert thine Vncles keeper?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: And the brace of Babouns anſwer'd, yes; and ſaid, thou wert a pittifull poore fellow, and did'ſt liue vpon poſts: and had'ſt nothing but three Sutes of Apparell, and ſome few Beneuolences that Lords ga'thee to foole to hem, and ſwagger.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Let mee not liue, I'll beate 'hem. I'll binde 'hem both to grand Madames Bed. poſtes, and haue 'hem bayted with Monkeyes.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt not need, they ſhall bee beaten to thy hand, Dauphine. I haue an Execution to ſerue vpon 'hem, I warrant thee ſhall ſerue: truſt my plot.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: I, you haue many plots! So you had one, to make all the Wenches in loue with mee.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Why, If I doe not yet afore night, as neere as 'tis; and that they doe not euery one inuite thee, and bee ready to ſcratch for thee: take the morgage of my wit.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: 'Fore God, I'll bee his witneſſe; thou ſhalt haue it, Dauphine: thou ſhalt bee his Foole for euer, if thou doeſt not.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p:
Agreed. Perhaps 'twill bee the better eſtate. Doe you obſerue this Gallerie? or rather Lobby, indeed? Here are a couple of Studies, at each end one: here will I act ſuch a Tragi-comoedy betweene the Cuelphes, and the Ghibellines,
Daw and La-Foole—which of 'hem comes out firſt, will I ſeize on: (you two ſhall be the Chorus behind the Arras, and whip out betweene the Acts, and ſpeake.) If I doe not make 'hem keepe the peace, for this remnant of the day, if not of the yeere, I haue faild once—I heare Daw comming: Hide, and doe not laugh, for Gods ſake.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Which is the way into the Garden, trow?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: O, Iack Daw! I am glad I haue met with you. In good faith, I muſt haue this matter goe no furder betweene you. I muſt ha' it taken vp.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: What matter, Sir? Betweene whom?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Come, you diſguiſe it—Sir Amorous and you. If you loue me, Iack, you ſhal make vſe of your Philoſophy now, for this once, and deliuer me your Sword. This is not the Wedding the Centaures were at, though there be a ſhee-one here. The Bride has entreated mee I will ſee no bloud ſhed at her Bridall, you ſaw her whiſper me ere-while.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: As I hope to finiſh Tacitus, I intend no Murder.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Doe you not wait for Sir Amorous?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Not I, by my Knight-hood.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: And your Schollerſhip too?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: And my Schollerſhip too.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Goe to, then I returne you your Sword, and aske you mercy; but put it not vp, for you will bee aſſaulted. I vnderſtood that you had apprehended it, and walkt here to braue him: and that you had held your life contemptible, in regard of your honour.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: No, no, no ſuch thing I aſſure you. He and I parted now, as good fileds as could be.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Truſt not you to that Viſor. I ſaw him ſince Dinner with another face: I haue knowne many men in my time vex'd with loſſes, with doeths, and with abuſes, but ſo offended a Wight as Sir Amorous, did I neuer ſee, or read of. For taking away his Gueſts, Sir, to day, that's the cauſe: and he declares it behind your back; with ſuch threatnings and centempts—Hee ſaid to Dauphine, you were the errandſt Aſſe—

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: I, he may ſay his pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: And ſweares you are ſo proteſted a Coward, that hee knowes you will neuer doe him any manly or ſingle right, and therefore he will take his courſe.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: I'll giue him any ſatisfaction, Sir—but fighting.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: I, Sir, but who knowes what ſatisfaction hee'll take? bloud hee thirſts for, and bloud hee will haue: and where-abouts on you he will haue it, who knowes but himſelfe?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: I pray you, Maſter Tru-wit, be you a Mediator.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: He puts him vp. Well, Sir, conceale your ſelfe then in this ſtudie, till I returne. Nay, you muſt bee content to bee lock'd in: for, for mine owne reputation I would not haue you ſeene to receiue a publique diſgrace, while I haue the matter in managing. Gods ſo, here hee comes: keepe your breath cloſe, that he doe not heare you ſigh. In good faith, Sir Amorous, he is not this way, I pray you be mercifull, doe not murder him; hee is a Chriſtian as good as you: you are arm'd as if you ſought a reuenge on all his Race. Good Dauphine, get him away from this place. I neuer knew a mans choller ſo high, but hee would ſpeake to his friends, he would heare reaſon. Iack Daw, Iack Daw! a-ſleepe?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Is he gone, Maſter Tru-wit?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: I, did you heare him?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: O God, yes.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: What a quicke eare feare has?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: But is he ſo arm'd, as you ſay?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Arm'd? did you euer ſee a fellow, ſet out to take poſſeſſion?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: I, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: That may giue you ſome light, to conceiue of him: but 'tis nothing to the principall. Some falſe Brother i'the houſe has furniſh'd him ſtrangely. Or, if it were out o' the houſe, it was Tom Otter.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Indeed, hee's a Captaine, and his Wife is his Kinſwoman.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Hee has got ſome-bodies old two-hand-ſword to mow you off at the knees. And that Sword hath ſpawn'd ſuch a Dagger!—but then he is ſo hung with Pikes, Halberds, Peitro • ells, Calliuers, and Muskets, that hee lookes like a Iuſtice of Peace's Hall: a man of two thouſand a yeere, is not ſeſſ'd at ſo many weapons, as he has on. There was neuer Fencer challeng'd at ſo many ſeuerall Foyles. You would think he meant to murder all Saint Pulehres Pariſh. If he could but victuall himſelfe for halfe a yeere, in his breeches, he is ſufficiently arm'd to ouer-runne a Countrie.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Good Lord, what meanes he, Sir! I pray you Maſter Tru-wit, be you a Mediator?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Well, I'll try if he will be appeas'd with a Legge or an Arme, if not you muſt die once.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: I would be loth to looſe my right Arme, for writing Madrigalls.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Why, if hee will bee ſatisfied with a thumb, or a little finger, all's one to me. You muſt think, I'll do my beſt.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Good Sir, doe.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: He puts him vp againe, and then came forth. What haſt thou done?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: He will let me doe nothing, man, hee do's all afore me, he offers his left arme.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: His left wing, for a Iack Daw.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Take it, by all meanes.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: How! Maime a man for euer, for a ieſt? what a conſcience haſt thou?

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: 'Tis no loſſe to him: hee has no employment for his Armes, but to eat ſpoone-meat. Beſide, as goods maime his bodie as his reputation.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Hee is a Scholler, and a Wit, and yet hee do's not thinke ſo. But he looſes no reputation with vs, for we all reſolu'd him an Aſſe before. To your places againe.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I pray thee, let me be in at the other a little.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Looke, you'll ſpoyle all: theſe be euer your tricks.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: No, but I could hit of ſomethings that thou wilt miſſe, and thou wilt ſay are good ones.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: I warrant you. I pray forbeare, I'll leaue it off, elſe.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Come away, Clerimont.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Sir Amorous!

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: Maſter Tru-wit.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Whither were you going?

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: Downe into the Court, to make water.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: By no meanes, Sir, you ſhall rather tempt your breeches.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: Why, Sir?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Enter here, if you loue your life.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: Why! why!

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Queſtion till your throat be cut, doe: dally till the enraged ſoule find you.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Daw it is: will you in?

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: I, I, I'll in: what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Nay, if hee had beene coole inough to tell vs that, there had beene ſome hope to attone you, but hee ſeemes ſo implacably enrag'd.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: 'Slight, let him rage. I'll hide my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Doe, good Sir. But what haue you done to him within, that ſhould prouoke him thus? you haue broke ſome Ieſt vpon him, a-fore the Ladies—

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: Not I, neuer in my life, broke Ieſt vpon any man. The Bride was prayſing Sir Dauphine, and he went away in ſnuffe, and I followed him, vnleſſe he tooke offence at me, in his drink ere while, that I would not pledge al the horſe full.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: By my faith, and that may be, you remember well: but he walkes the round vp and down, through euery roome o'the houſe, with a Towell in his hand, crying, where's La-Foole? who ſaw La-Foole? and when Dauphine, and I, demanded the cauſe, wee can force no anſwere f • om him, but (ô reuenge, how ſweete art thou! I will ſtrangle him in this Towell) which leads vs to coniecture, that the maine cauſe of his furie is for bringing your meate to day, with a Towell about you, to his diſcredit.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: Like inough. Why, and he be angry for that. I'll ſtay here, till his anger be blowne ouer.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: A good becomming reſolution, Sir. If you can put it on o' the ſudden.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: Yes, I can put it on. Or, I'll away into the Countrey preſently.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: How will you get out o'the houſe, Sir? Hee knowes you are i' the houſe, and hee'll watch you this ſe'n-night but hee'll haue you. Hee'll out-wait a Seriant for you.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: Why, then I'll ſtay here.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: You muſt thinke, how to victuall your ſelfe in time, then.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: Why, ſweet Maſter Tru-wit, will you entreat my Couſin Otter, to ſend me a cold Veniſon Paſty, a Bottle or two of Wine, and a Chamber Pot.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: A ſtoole were better, Sir, of Sir A-iax his inuention.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: I, that will be better indeed: and a Pallat to lye on.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: O, I would not aduiſe you to ſleepe by any meanes.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: Would you not, Sir? why, then I will not.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Yet, there's another feare—

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: Is there, Sir? What is't?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: No, hee cannot breake open this doore with his foote, ſure.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: I'll ſet my backe againſt it, Sir. I haue a good backe.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: But, then if he ſhould batter.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: Batter! if he dare, I'll haue an Action of Batt'ry, againſt him.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Caſt you the worſt. Hee has ſent for poulder alreadie, and what he will doe with it, no man knowes: perhaps blow vp the corner o'the houſe where bee ſuſpects you are. Here he comes, in quickly. I proteſt, Sir Iohn Daw, Hee faines as if one were preſent, to fright the other, who is run in to hide himſelfe. he is not this way: what will you doe? before God, you ſhall ha •• g no petar de here. I'll dye rather Will you not take my word? I neuer knew one but would be ſatisfied. Sir Amorous, there's no ſtanding out. Hee has made a petarde of an olde braſſe Pot, to force your doore. Thinke vpon ſome ſatisfaction or termes, to offer him.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: Sir, I'll giue him any ſatisfaction. I dare giue any termes.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: You'll leaue it to me, then?

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: I, Sir. I'll ſtand to any conditions.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Hee cals forth Clerimont, and Dauphine. How now, what thinke you, Sirs? were't not a difficult thing to determine, which of theſe two fear'd moſt.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Yes, but this feares the braueſt: the other a whiniling daftard, Iack Daw: but La-Foole, a braue heroique coward! and is afraid in a great looke, and a ſtout accent. I like him rarely.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Had it not beene pitty, theſe two ſhould ha'beene conceal'd?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Shall I make a motion?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Briefly. For I muſt ſtrike while 'tis hot.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Shall I goe fetch the Ladies to the Catastrophe?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Vmh? I, by my troth.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: By no mortall meanes. Let them continue in the ſtate of ignorance, and erre ſtill: thinke 'hem wits, and fine fellowes, as they haue done. 'Twere ſinne to reforme them.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Well, J will haue 'hem fetch'd, now I thinke on't, for a priuate purpoſe of mine: doe, Clerimont, fetch 'hem, and diſcourſe to 'hem all that's paſt, and bring 'hem into the Gallery here.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: This is thy extreme vanitie, now: thou think'ſt thou wert vndone, if euery Ieſt thou mak'ſt were not publiſh'd.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt ſee, how vniuſt thou art, preſently. Clerimont, ſay it was Dauphine's plot. Truſt mee not, if the whole drift bee not for thy good. There's a Carpet i' the next roome, put it on, with this Scarfe ouer thy face, and a Cuſhion o' thy head, and be ready when I call Amorous. Away—.Iohn Daw.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: What good newes, Sir?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Faith, I haue followed, and argued with him hard for you. I told him, you were a Knight, and a Scholler; and that you knew fortitude did conſiſt magis patiendo quam faciendo, magis ferendo quam feriendo.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: It doth ſo indeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: And that you would ſuffer, I told him: ſo, at firſt he demanded, by my troth, in my conceipt, too much.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: What was it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Your vpper lip, and ſix o' your fore-teeth.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: 'Twas vnreaſonable.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Nay, I told him plainly, you could not ſpare 'hem all. So after long argument (pro & con, as you know) I brought him downe to your two Butter-teeth, and them he would haue.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: O, did you ſo? why, he ſhall haue 'hem.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: But he ſhall not, Sir, by your leaue. The concluſion is this, Sir, becauſe you ſhall be very good friends hereafter, and this neuer to be remembred, or vpbrayded; beſides, that he may not boaſt, he has done any ſuch thing to you in his owne perſon: hee is to come here in diſguiſe, giue you fiue kicks in priuate, Sir, take your Sword from you, and lock you vp in that Studie, during pleaſure. Which will be but a little while, wee'll get it releas'd preſently.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Fiue kicks? he ſhall haue ſix, Sir, to be friends.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Beleeue me, you ſhall not ouer-ſhoot your ſelfe, to ſend him that word by me.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Deliuer it, Sir. He ſhall haue it with all my heart, to be friends.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Friends? Nay, and he ſhould not be ſo, and heartily too, vpon theſe termes, he ſhall haue me to enemie while I liue. Come, Sir, beare it brauely.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: O God, Sir, 'tis nothing.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Tru. What's ſix kicks to a man, that reades Seneca?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: I haue had a hundred, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Sir Amorous. No ſpeaking one to another, Dauphine comes forth, and kicks him. or rehearſing old matters.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: One, two, three, foure, fiue. I proteſt, Sir Amorous, you ſhall haue ſix.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p:
Nay, I told you ſhould not talke. Come giue him ſix, and he will needs. Your Sword. Now returne to your ſafe cuſtody: you ſhall preſently meete afore the Ladies, and be
the deareſt friends one to another—Giue mee the Scarfe, now, thou ſhalt beat the other bare-fac'd. Stand by, Sir Amorous.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: What's here? A Sword.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: I cannot helpe it, without I ſhould take the quarrell vpon my ſelfe: here he has ſent you his Sword—

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: I ll receiue none on't.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: And hee wils you to faſten it againſt a wall, and breake your head in ſome few ſeuerall places againſt the Hilts.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: I will not: tell him roundly. I cannot endure to ſhed my owne bloud.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Will you not?

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: No. I ll beat it againſt a faire flat wall, if that will ſatisfie him: If not, he ſhall beat it himſelfe, for Amorous.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Why, this is ſtrange ſtarting off, when a man vndertakes for you! I offered him another condition: will you ſtand to that?

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: Yes, I am content, at the blunt.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Then you muſt ſubmit your ſelfe to bee hood-wink'd in this Skarſe, and bee led to him, where hee will take your Sword from you, and make you beare a blow, ouer the Mouth, Gules, and tweakes by the Noſe, Sans numbre.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: I am content. But why muſt I be blinded?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: That's for your good, Sir: becauſe, if hee ſhould grow inſolent vpon this, and publ • ſh it hereafter to your diſgrace (which I hope hee will not doe) you might ſweare ſafely and proteſt, hee neuer beate you to your knowledge.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: O, I conceiue.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: I doe not doubt, but you'll bee perfect good friends vpon't, and not dare to vtter an ill thought one of another, in future.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: Not I, as God helpe me, of him.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Nor he of you, Sir. If he ſhould—Come, Sir. All hid, Sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: Oh, Sir Iohn, Sir Iohn. Dauphine enters to tweake him, Oh, ô-ô ô ô ô Oh—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Good Sir Iohn, leaue tweaking, you'll blow his Noſe off. 'Tis Sir Iohn's pleaſure, you ſhould retyre into the Studie. Why, now you are friendes. All bitterneſſe betweene you, I hope, is buried; you ſhall come forth by and by, Damon and Pythias vpon't: and embrace with all the rankneſſe of Friendſhip that can bee. I truſt, we ſhall haue 'hem tamer i'their Language hereafter. Dauphine, I worſhip thee. Gods will, the Ladies haue ſurpris'd vs!

div.head: Act IIII. Scene VI.
div.stage: Hauing diſcouerd part of the paſt Scene aboue:
Haughty, Centaure, Mauis, Miſtris Otter, Epicoene, Trusty, Dauphine, Tru-wit, &c.

sp.p: CEntaure, how our iudgements were impos'd on by theſe adulterate Knights!

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: Nay, Madame, Mauis was more deceiu'd then wee, 'twas her commendation vtter'd 'hem in the Colledge.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: I commended but their wits, Madame, and their braueries. I neuer look'd toward their valours.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Sir Dauphine is valiant, and a wit too, it ſeemes.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: And a brauery too.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Was this his proiect?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: So Maſter Clerimont intimates, Madame.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Good Moroſe, when you come to the Colledge, will you bring him with you? Hee ſeemes a very perfect Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: He is ſo Madame, beleeue it.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: But when will you come, Moroſe?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Three or foure dayes hence, Madame, when I haue got me a Coach, and Horſes.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: No, to morrow, good Moroſe, Centaure ſhall ſend you her Coach.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: Yes faith, doe, and bring Sir Dauphine with you.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Shee has promis'd that Mauis.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: Hee is a very worthy Gentleman, in his exteriors, Madame.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: I, he ſhowes he is iudiciall in his clothes.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: And yet not ſo ſuperlatiuely neat as ſome, Madame, that haue their faces ſet in a Brake!

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: I, and haue euery haire in forme!

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: That weare purer Linnen then our ſelues, and profeſſe more neatneſſe, then the French Hermaphrodite!

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I Ladies, they, what they tell one of vs, haue tolde a thouſand, and are the only Theeues of our fame: that thinke to take vs with that Perfume, or with that Lace, and laugh at vs vn-conſcionably when they haue done.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: But, Sir Dauphines careleſneſſe becomes him.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: I could loue a man, for ſuch a Noſe!

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: Or ſuch a Legge!

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: He has an exceeding good eye, Madame!

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: And a very good Lock!

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: Good Moroſe, bring him to my Chamber firſt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: Pleaſe your Honours, to meete at my Houſe, Madame?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: See, how they eye thee, man! they are taken I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: You haue vnbrac'd our brace of Knights, heere, Maſter Tru-wit.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Not I, Madame, it was Sir Dauphines inginer: who, if he haue disfurniſh'd your Ladiſhip of any guard, or ſeruice by it, is able to make the place good againe, in himſelf.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: There's no ſuſpition of that, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: God ſo, Mauis, Haughty is kiſſing.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: Let vs goe too, and take part.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: But I am glad of the fortune (beſide the diſcouerie of two ſuch emptie Caskets) to gaine the knowledge of ſo rich a Mine of Vertue, as Sir Dauphine.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: Wee would bee all glad to ſtile him of our friendſhip, and ſee him at the Colledge.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: Hee cannot mixe with a ſweeter ſocietie, I'll propheſie, and I hope he himſelfe will thinke ſo.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: I ſhould be rude to imagine otherwiſe, Ladie.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Did not I tell thee, Dauphine? Why, all their actions are gouerned by crude opinion, without reaſon or cauſe; they know not why they doe any thing: but as they are inform'd, beleeue, iudge, prayſe, condemne, loue, hate, and in aemulation one of another, doe all theſe things alike. Onely, they haue a naturall inclination ſwayes 'hem generally to the worſt, when they are left to themſelues. But, purſue it, now thou haft 'hem.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Shall we goe in againe, Moroſe?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Yes, Madame.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: Wee'll entreate Sir Dauphines company.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Stay, good Madame, the inter-view of the two friends, Pylades and Oreſtes: I'll fetch 'hem out to you ſtraight.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Will you, Maſter Tru-wit?

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: I, but noble Ladies, do not confeſſe in your countenance, or outward bearing to 'hem any diſcouerie of their follies, that wee may ſee, how they will beare vp againe, with what aſſurance, and erection.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: We will not, Sir Dauphine.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: Mau. Vpon our honours, Sir Dauphine.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Sir Amorous, Sir Amorous. The Ladies are here.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: Are they?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Yes, but ſlip out by and by, as their backes are turn'd, and meet Sir Iohn here, as by chance, when I call you. Iack Daw.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: What ſay you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Whip out behinde mee ſuddenly: and no anger i' your lookes to your Aduerſarie. Now, now.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: Noble Sir Iohn Daw! where ha' you beene?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: To ſeeke you, Sir Amorous.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: Me! I honour you.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: I preuent you▪ Sir.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: They haue forgot their Rapiers!

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: O, they meet in peace, man.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Where's your Sword, Sir Iohn?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: And yours, Sir Amorous?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Mine! my Boy had it forth, to mend the handle, cene now.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: And my gold handle was broke too, and my Boy had it forth.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir? How their excuſes meet!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: What a conſent there is, i' the handles?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Nay, there is ſo i' the points too, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: O me! Madame, hee comes againe, the madde man, away.
Hee had ſound the two Swords drawne within. WHat make theſe naked weapons here, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: O, Sir! here hath like to beene muder ſince you went! A couple of Knights fallen out about the Brides fauours: we were faine to take away their weapons, your houſe had beene begg'd by this time elſe—

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: For Man ſlaughter, Sir, as being acceſſary.

sp.speaker: Mor,
sp.p: And, for her fauours?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: I, Sir, heretofore, not preſent. Clerimont, carrie 'hem their Swords, now. They haue done all the hurt they will doe.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Ha' you ſpoke with a Lawyer, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p:
O, no! there is ſuch a noyſe i' the Court, that they haue frighted me home, with more violence then I went! ſuch ſpeaking, and counter-ſpeaking, with their ſeuerall voyces of Citations, Appellations, Allegations, Certificates,
Attachments, Intergatories, References, Conuictions, and Afflictions indeed, among the Doctors and Proctors! that the noyſe here is ſilence too't! a kind of mid-night!

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Why, Sir, if you would bee reſolu'd indeed, I can bring you hither a very ſufficient Lawyer, and a Learned Diuine, that ſhall inquire into euery leaſt ſcruple for you.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Can you Maſter Tru-wit?
Yes, and are very ſober graue perſons, that will diſpatch it in a Chamber, with a whiſper, or two.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Good Sir, ſhall I hope this benefit from you, and truſt my ſelfe into your hands?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Alas, Sir! your Nephew, and I, haue beene aſham'd, and oft-times mad ſince you went, to thinke how you are abus'd. Goe in, good Sir, and locke your ſelfe vp till we call you, wee'll tell you more anon, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Doe your pleaſure with mee, Gentlemen; I beleeue in you: and that deſerues no deluſion—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: You ſhall find none, Sir: but heapt, heapt plentie of vexation.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: What wilt thou doe now, Wit?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Recouer me hither Otter, and the Barber if you can, by any meanes, preſently.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Why? to what purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: O, I'll make the deepeſt Diuine, and graueſt Lawyer, out o' them two, for him—

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Thou canſt not man, theſe are waking Dreames.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Doe not feare mee. Clap but a Ciuill Gowne with a Welt, o' the one; and a Canonicall Cloke with Sleeues, o' the other: and giue 'hem a few termes i' their mouthes, if there come not forth as able a Doctor, and compleat a Parſon, for this turne, as may bee wiſh'd, truſt not my Election. And, I hope without wronging the dignitie of eyther Profeſſion, ſince they are but perſons put on, and for mirths ſake, to torment him. The Barber ſmatters Latine, I remember.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Yes, and Otter too.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Well then, if I make 'hem not wrangle out this Caſe, to his no comfort, let mee bee thought a lack Daw, or La-Foole, or any thing worſe, Goe you to your Ladies, but firſt ſend for them.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: I will.
WHere had you our Swords, Maſter Clerimont?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Why, Dauphine tooke 'hem from the madman.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: And hee tooke 'hem from our Boyes, I warrant you?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Very like, Sir.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: Thanke you good Maſter Clerimont. Sir Iohn Daw, and I are both beholden to you.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Would I knew how to make you ſo, Gentlemen:

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Sir Amorous, and I are your Seruants, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: Gentlemen, haue any of you a Pen-and-Inke. I would faine write out a Riddle in Italian, for Sir Dauphine, to tranſlate.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Not I, in troth Lady, I am no Scriuener.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: I can furniſh you, I thinke, Lady.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: He has it in the Haft of a Knife, I beleeue!

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: No, he has his Boxe of Inſtruments.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Like a Surgean!

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: For the Mathematiques: his Squire, his Compaſſes, his Braſſe Pens, and Black-lead, to draw Maps of euery place, and perſon, where he comes.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: How, Maps of perſons!

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, of Nomentack, when he was here, and of the Prince of Moldauia, and of Miſtris, Miſtris Epicane.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Away! he has not found our her Latitude, I hope.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: You are a pleaſant Gentleman, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Faith, now we are in priuate, let's wanton it a little, and talke waggiſhly. Sir Iohn, I am telling Sir Amorous here, that you two gouerne the Ladies, where e're you come. you carry the Feminine Gender afore you.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: They ſhall rather carry vs afore them, if they will, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Nay, I beleeue that they doe, withall—But, that you are the prime-men in their affections, and direct all their actions—

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Not I: Sir Amorous is.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: I proteſt, Sir Iohn is.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: As I hope to riſe i' the ſtate, Sir Amorous, you ha' the perſon.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: Sir Iohn, you ha' the perſon, and the Diſcourſe too.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Not I, Sir. I haue no diſcourſe—and then you haue actiuitie beſide.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: I proteſt, Sir Iohn, you come as high from Tripoly, as I doe euery whit: and lift as many ioyn'd ſtooles, and leape ouer 'hem, if you would vſe it—

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Well, agree on't together Knights; for betweene you, you diuide the Kingdome, or Common-wealth of Ladies affections: I ſee it, and can perceiue a little how they obſerue you, and fear you, indeed. You could tell ſtrange Stories, my Maſters, if you would, I know.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Faith, we haue ſeene ſomewhat, Sir.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: That we haue—Vellet Petticoates, and wrought Smocks, or ſo.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: I, and—
Nay, out with it, Sir Iohn: doe not enuie your friend the pleaſure of hearing, when you haue had the delight of taſting.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Why—a—doe you ſpeake, Sir Amorous.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: No, doe you, Sir Iohn Daw.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: I'faith, you ſhall.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: I'faith, you ſhall.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Why, we haue beene—

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: In the great Bed at Ware together in our time. On, Sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Nay, doe you, Sir Amorous.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: And theſe Ladies with you, Knights?

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: No, excuſe vs, Sir.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: We muſt not wound reputation.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: No matter—they were theſe, or others. Our bath coſt vs fifteene pound, when we came home.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Doe you heare, Sir Iohn, you ſhall tell mee but one thing truly, as you loue me.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: If I can, I will, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: You lay in the ſame houſe with the Bride, here?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Yes, and conuerſt with her hourely, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: And what humour is ſhe of? is ſhee comming, and open, free?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: O, exceeding open, Sir. I was her Seruant, and Sir Amorous was to be.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Come, you haue both had fauours from her? I know, and haue heard ſo much.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: O, no, Sir.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: You ſhall excuſe vs, Sir: we muſt not wound reputation.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Tut, ſhe is marryed, now; and you cannot hurt her with any report, and therefore ſpeake plainly: how many times, yfaith? which of you lead firſt? Ha?

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: Sir Iohn had her Mayden-head, indeed.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: O, it pleaſes him to ſay ſo, Sir, but Sir Amorous knowes what's what, as well.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Do'ſt thou yfaith, Amorous?

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: In a manner, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Why, I commend you Lads. Little knowes Don Bride groome of this. Nor ſhall he, for me.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Hang him, mad Oxe.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Speake ſoftly: here comes his Nephew, with the Ladie Haughty. Hee'll get the Ladies from you, Sirs, if you looke not to him in time.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: Why, if he doe, wee'll fetch 'hem home againe, I warrant you.

IAſſure you, Sir Dauphine, it is the price and eſtimation of your vertue only, that hath embarqu'd mee to this aduenture, and I could not but make out to tell you; nor can I repent me of the act, ſince it is alwayes an argument of ſome vertue in our ſelues, that wee loue and affect it ſo in others.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Your Ladiſhip ſets too high a price, on my weakneſſe.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Sir, I can diſtinguiſh Gemmes from Peebles—

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: (Are you ſo skilfull in Stones?)

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: And, howſoever I may ſuffer in ſuch a iudgement as yours, by admitting equality of ranke, or ſocietie, with Centaure or Mauis—

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: You doe not, Madame, I perceiue they are your mere Foyles.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Then are you a friend to truth, Sir. It makes mee loue you the more. It is not the outward, but the inward man that I affect. They are not apprehenſiue of an eminent perfection, but loue flat, and dully.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: Where are you, my Lady Haughty.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: I come preſently, Centawe. My Chamber, Sir, my Page ſhall ſhow you; and Trusty, my woman, ſhall be euer a wake for you: you neede not feare to communicate any thing with her, for ſhee is a Fidelia. I pray you weare this Iewell for my ſake, Sir Dauphine. Where's Mauis, Centaure?

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: Within, Madame, a writing. I'll follow you preſently. I'll but ſpeake a word with Sir Dauphine.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: With me, Madame?

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: Good Sir Dauphine, doe not truſt Haughty, nor make any credit to her, what euer you doe beſides. Sir Dauphine, I giue you this caution, ſhee is a perfect Courtier; and loues no body, but for her vſes: and for her vſes, ſhe loues all. Beſides, her Phiſicians giue her out to be none o'the cleereſt, whether ſhe pay 'hem or no, Heau'n knowes: and ſhe's abode fiftie too, and pargets! See her in a fore-noone. Heere comes Mauis, a worſe face then ſhee! you would not like this, by Candle-light. If you'll come to my Chamber one o' theſe Mornings early, or late in an Euening, I'll tell you more. Where's Haughty, Mauis?

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: Within, Centaure.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: What ha' you, there?

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: An Italian Riddle for Sir Dauphine, (you ſhall not ſee it yfaith, Centaure.) Good Sir Dauphine, ſolue it for me. I'll call for it anon.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: How now, Dauphine? how do'ſt thou quit thy ſelfe of theſe Females?

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: 'Slight, they haunt meelike Fayries, and giue mee Iewels here, I cannot be rid of 'hem,

sp.speaker: Cle
sp.p: O, you muſt not tell, though.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Maſſe, I forgot that: I was neuer ſo aſſaulted. One loues for vertue, and bribes mee with this. Another loues mee with caution, and ſo would poſſeſſe mee. A third brings mee a Riddle here, and all are iealous: and raile each at other.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: He reades the Paper. A Riddle? pray le' mee ſee't? Sir Dauphine, I choſe this way of intimation for priuacie. The Ladies here, I know, haue both hope, and purpoſe, to make a Collegiate and Seruant of you. If I might bee ſo honour'd, as to appeare at any end of ſo noble a Worke, I would enter into a fame of taking Phiſicke to morrow, and continue you it foure or fiue dayes, or longer, for your viſitation. Mauis. By my faith, a ſubtle one! Call you this a Riddle? What's their plaine dealing, trow?

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: We lack Tru-wit, to tell vs that.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Wee lacke him for ſomewhat elſe too: his Knights reformados are wound vp as high, and inſolent, as euer they were.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: You ieſt.

sp.speaker: Cle,
sp.p: No Drunkards, either with Wine or Vanitie, euer confeſſ'd ſuch Stories of themſelues. I would not giue a Flyes legge, in ballauce againſt all the womens reputations here, if they could be but thought to ſpeake truth: and, for the Bride, they haue made their affidauit againſt her directly—

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: What, they haue lyen with her?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Yes, and tell times, and circumſtances, with the cauſe why, and the place where. I had almoſt brought 'hem to affirme that they had done it, to day.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Not both of 'hem.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Yes faith: with a ſooth or two more I had effected it. They would ha' ſet it downe vnder their hands.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Why, they will bee our ſport, I ſee, ſtill! whether we will, or no.

div.head: Act V. Scene III.
div.stage: Tru-wit, Moroſe, Otter, Cutberd, Clerimont, Dauphine.

sp.p:
O, Are you here? Come Dauphine, Goe call your Vncle preſently. I haue fitted my Diuine, and my Canoniſt, dyed their Beards and all: the Knaues doe not know themſelues they are ſo exalted, and alter'd. Preferment changes any man. Thou ſhalt keepe one doore, and I another, and then Clerimont in the midſt, that hee may haue no meanes of eſcape from their cauilling, when they grow hot once againe. And then the women (as I haue giuen the Bride her inſtructions) to breake in vpon him, i' the l'enuoy. O, 'twill bee full and twanging! Away, fetch him. Come, Maſter Doctor, and Maſter Parſon, looke to your parts now, and diſcharge 'hem brauely: you are well ſet forth, performe
it as well. If you chance to be out, doe not confeſſe it with ſtanding ſtill, or humming, or gaping one at another: but go on, and talke alowd, and eagerly, vſe vehement action, and onely remember your termes, and you are ſafe. Let the matter goe where it will: you haue many will doe ſo. But at firſt, be very ſolemne, and graue like your garments, though you loſe your ſelues after, and skip out like a brace of Iugglers on a Table. Here he comes! ſet your faces, and looke ſuperciliouſly, while I preſent you.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Are theſe the two learned men?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, pleaſe you ſalute 'hem?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Salute 'hem? I had rather doe any thing, then weare out time ſo vnfruitfully, Sir. I wonder, how theſe common formes, as God ſaue you, and you are well-come, are come to be a habit in our liues! or, I am glad to ſee you! when I cannot ſee, what the profit can be of theſe words, ſo long as it is no whit better with him, whoſe affaires are ſad, and grieuous, that he heares this ſalutation.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: 'Tis true, Sir, wee'll goe to the matter then. Gentlemen, Maſter Doctor, and Maſter Parſon, I haue acquainted you ſufficiently with the buſineſſe, for which you are come hither. And you are not now to enforme your ſelues in the ſtate of the queſtion, I know. This is the Gentleman, who expects your reſolution, and therefore, when you pleaſe, begin.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Pleaſe you, Maſter Doctor.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Pleaſe you, good Maſter Parſon.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: I would heare the Canon law ſpeake firſt.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: It muſt giue place to poſitiue Diunitie, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p:
Nay, good Gentlemen, doe not throw me into circumſtances. Let your comforts ar • iue quickly at me, thoſe that are. Be ſwift in affoording mee my peace, if ſo I ſhall hope any. I loue not your Diſpurations, or your Court-tumults. And that it be not ſtrange to you, I will tell you. My Father, in my education, was woont to aduiſe mee, that I ſhould alwayes collect, and contayne my mind, not ſuffring
it to flow looſely; that I ſhould looke to what things were neceſſarie to the carriage of my life, and what not: embracing the one and eſchewing the other. In ſhort, that I ſhould endeare my ſelfe to reſt, and auoid turmoile: which now is growne to bee another nature to mee. So that I come not to your publike pleadings, or your places of noyſe; not that I neglect thoſe things, that make for the dignitie of the Common-wealth: but for the meere auoyding of clamours, and impertinences of Orators, that know not how to bee ſilent. Aud for the cauſe of noyſe, am I now a ſutor to you You doe not know in what a miſerie I haue beene exercis'd this day, what a torrent of euill! My very Houſe turnes round with the tumult! I dwell in a Wind-mill! The perpetuall about motion is here, and not at Eltham.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Well, good Maſter Doctor, will you breake the ice? Maſter parſon will wade after.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Sir, though vnworthy, and the weaker, I will preſume.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: 'Tis no preſumption, Domine Doctor.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Yet againe!

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Your queſtion is, for how many cauſes a man may haue diuortium legitimum, a lawfull Diuorce. Firſt, you muſt vnderſtand the nature of the word Diuorce, a diuertendo—

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No excurſions vpon words, good Doctor, to the queſtion briefly.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: I anſwere then, the Canon-law affords Diuorce but in few caſes, and the principall is in the common caſe, the adulterous caſe. But there are duodecim impedimenta, twelue impediments (as wee call 'hem) all which doe not dirimere contractum, but irritum reddere matrimonium, as wee ſay in the Canon-law, not take away the bond, but cauſe a nullitie therein.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I vnderſtood you, before: good Sir, auoyd your impertinencie of Tranſlation.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: He cannot open this too much, Sir, by your fauour.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Yet more!

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: O, you muſt giue the learned men leaue, Sir. To your impediments, Maſter Doctor.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: The firſt is impedimentum erroris.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Of which there are ſeuerall ſpecies.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: I, as error perſonae.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: If you contract your ſelfe to one perſon, thinking her another.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Then, error fortunae.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: If ſhe be a Begger, and you thought her rich.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Then, error qualitatis.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: If ſhee prooue ſtubborne, or head-ſtrong, that you thought obedient.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: How? is that, Sir, a lawfull impediment? One at once, I pray you Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: I, ante copulam, but not post copulam, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Maſter Parſon ſayes right. Nec poſt nuptiarum benedictionem. It doth indeed but irrita reddere ſponſalia, annull the Contract: after Marriage it is of no obſtancy.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Alas, Sir, what a hope are wee fall'n from, by this time!

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: The next is conditio: if you thought her free borne, and ſhee prooue a bond-woman, there is impediment of eſtate and condition.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: I, but Maſter Doctor, thoſe ſeruitudes are ſubla •• e, now, among vs Chriſtians.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: By your fauour, Maſter Parſon—

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: You ſhall giue me leaue, Maſter Doctor.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Nay, Gentlemen, quarrell not in that queſtion; it concernes not my caſe: paſſe to the third.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Well then, the third is votum. If either partie haue made a vow of Chaſtitie. But that practice, as Maſter Parſon ſaid of the other, is taken away among vs, thankes bee to diſcipline. The fourth is cognatio: if the perſons bee of kinne, within the degrees.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: I: doe you know, what the degrees are, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No, nor I care not, Sir: they offer me no comfort in the queſtion, I am ſure,

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: But, there is a branch of this impediment may, which is cognatio ſpiritualis. If you were her Godfather, Sir, then the Marriage is inceſtuous.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: That comment is abſurd, and ſuperſtitious, Maſter Doctor. I cannot endure it. Are wee not all Brothers and Siſters, and as much a kinne in that, as God-fathers, and God-daughters?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O me! to end the Controuerſie, I neuer was a Godfather, I neuer was a God-father id my life, Sir. Paſſe to the next.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: The ſift is crimen adulterij: the knowne Caſe. The ſixt, cultus diſparitas, difference of Religion: haue you euer examin'd her what Religion ſhe is of?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No, I would rather ſhee were of none, then bee put to the trouble of it!

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: You may haue it done for you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: By no meanes, good Sir, on to the reſt: ſhall you euer come to an end, thinke you?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Yes, he has done halfe, Sir. (On, to the reſt) be patient, and expect, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: The ſeuenth is, vis: if it were vpon compulſion, or force.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O no, it was too voluntary, mine: too voluntary.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: The eighth is, ordo: if euer ſhee haue taken holy Orders.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: That's ſuperſtitious, too.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No matter, Maſter Parſon: would ſhe would goe into a Nunnerie yet.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: The ninth is, ligamen: if you were bound, Sir, to any other before.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I thruſt my ſelfe too ſoone into theſe Fetters.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: The tenth is, publica honestas: which is inchoata quaedam affinitas.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: I, or affinitas orta ex ſponſalibus: and is but leue impedimentum.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I feele no ayre of comfort blowing to mee, in all this.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: The eleuenth is, affinitas ex fornicatione.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Which is no leſſe vera affinitas, then the other Maſter Doctor.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: True, quae oritur ex legitimo matrimonio.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: You ſay right, venerable Doctor. And, naſcitur ex co, quod per coniugium duae perſonae efficiuntur vna caro—

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Hey-day, now they beginne.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: I conceiue you, Maſter Parſon. Ita per fornicationem aeque est verus pater, qui ſic generat—

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Et vere filius qui ſic generatur—

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What's all this to me?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Now it growes warme.

sp.speaker: Cut.
