sp.p: The twelfth, and laſt is, ſi forte coire nequibis.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: I, that is impedimentum grauiſſimum. It doth vtterly annull, and annihilate, that. If you haue manifestam frigiditatem, you are well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Why, there is comfort come at length, Sir. Confeſſe your ſelfe but a man vnable, and ſhee will ſue to be diuorc'd firſt.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: I, or if there be morbus perpetuus, & inſanabilis, as Paralyſis, Elephantiaſis, or ſo—

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: O, but frigiditas is the fairer way, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: You ſay troth, Sir, and as it is in the Canon Maſter Doctor.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: I conceiue you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Before he ſpeakes.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: That a Boy, or child, vnder yeeres, is not fit for marriage, becauſe he cannot reddere debitum. So your omnipotentes—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Your impotentes, you whorſon Lobſter.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Your impotentes, I ſhould ſay, are minime apti ad contrahenda matrimonium.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Matrimonium? We ſhall haue moſt vn-matrimoniall Latin, with you: Matrimonia, and be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Doup.
sp.p: You put 'hem out, man.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: But then there will ariſe a doubt, Maſter Parſon, in our Caſe, post Matrimonium: that frigiditate praeditus (doe you conceiue me, Sir?)

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Very well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Who cannot vti vxore pro vxore, may habere cam pro ſorore.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Abſurd, abſurd, abſurd, and meerly Apostaticall.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: You ſhall pardon me, Maſter Parſon, I can proue it.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: You can prooue a Will, Maſter Doctor, you can prooue nothing elſe. Do's not the Verſe of your owne Caxan ſay, Haec ſocianda vetant connubia, facta retractant—

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: I grant you, but how doe they retractare, Maſter Parſon?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: (O, this was it, I fear'd.)

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: In aeternum, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: That's falſe in Diuinitie, by your fauour.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: 'Tis falſe in humanitie, to ſay ſo. Is hee not prorſus inutilis ad Thorum? Can he praeſtare fidem datam? I would faine know.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Yes: how if he doe conualere?

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: He cannot connulere, it is impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Nay, good Sir, attend the learned men, they'll thinke you neglect 'hem elſe.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Or, if he doe ſimulare himſelfe frigidum, odio vxoris, or ſo?

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: I ſay, he is adulter manifestus, then.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: (They diſpute it very learnedly, yfaith.)

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: And proſtitutor vxoris, and this is poſitiue.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Good Sir, let me eſcape.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: You will not doe me that wrong, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: And therefore, if he be manifeste frigidus, Sir—

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: I, if he be manifeſte frigidus, I grant you—

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Why, that was my concluſion.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: And mine too.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Nay, heare the concluſion, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Then frigiditatis cauſa—

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Yes, cauſa frigiditatis—

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O, mine eares!

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: She may haue libellum diuortij, againſt you.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: I, diuorty libellum ſhe will ſure haue.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Good Eccho's, forbeare.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: If you confeſſe it.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Which I would doe, Sir—

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I will doe any thing—

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: And cleere my ſelfe in Foro Conſcientiae—

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Becauſe you wanc indeed—

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Yet more?

div.head: Act V. Scene IIII.
div.stage: Epicoene, Moroſe, Haughty, Centaure, Mauis, Miſtris Otter, Daw, Tru-wit, Dauphine, Clerimont, La-Foole, Otter, Cutherd.

sp.p: I Wil not endure it any longer. Ladies, I beſeech you helpe me. This is ſuch a wrong, as neuer was offer'd to poore Bride before. Vpon her Marriage day, to haue her Huſband conſpire againſt her, and a couple of Mercinary Companions, to be brought in for formes ſake, to perſwade a Separation! If you had bloud, or vertue in you, Gentlemen, you would not ſuffer ſuch Eare-wigs about a Husband, or Scorpions, to creepe betweene Man and Wife—

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O, the varietie, and changes of my torment!

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Let 'hem bee cudgell'd out of doores, by our Groomes.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: I'll lend you my Foot-man.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: Wee'll haue our men blanket 'hem i'the Hall.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: As there was one, at our Houſe, Madame, for peeping in at the doore.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Content, yfaith.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Stay, Ladies, and Gentlemen, you'll heare, before uproceed?

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: I'lld ha' the Bride-groome blanketted, too.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: Begin with him firſt.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Yes, by my troth.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O, Mankind Generation!

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Ladies, for my ſake forbeare.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Yes, for Sir Dauphines ſake.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: He ſhall command vs.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: Hee is as fine a Gentleman of his inches, Madame, as any is about the Towne, and weares as good colours when he lift.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Bee briefe, Sir, and confeſſe your infirmitie, ſhee'll be a-fire to be quit of you, if ſhe but heare that nam'd once, you ſhall not entreat her to ſtay. Shee'll flye you, like one that had the markes vpon him.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ladies, I muſt craue all your pardons—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Silence, Ladies.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: For a wrong I haue done to your whole ſexe, in marrying this faire, and vertuous Gentlewoman—

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Heare him, good Ladies.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Being guiltie of an infirmitie, which before I conferr'd with theſe learned men, I thought I might haue conceald—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: But now being better inform'd in his conſcience by them, hee is to declare it, and giue ſatisfaction, by asking your publique forgiueneſſe.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I am no man, Ladies.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Vtterly vn-abled in nature, by reaſon of frigiditie, to performe the duties, or any the leaſt office of a Husband.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: Now, out vpon him, prodigious creature!

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: Bride-groome vn carnate.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: And would you offer it to a yong Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: A Lady of her longings?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Tut, a deuice, a deuice, this, it ſmels rankly, Ladies. A mere comment of his owne.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Why, if you ſuſpect that, Ladies, you may haue him ſearch'd.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: As the cuſtome is, by a Iurie of Phyſitians.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: Yes faith, 'twill be braue.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O me, muſt I vndergoe that!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: No, let women ſearch him, Madame: wee can doe it our ſelues.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Our on me, worſe!

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: No Ladies, you ſhall not need, I'll take him with all his faults.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Worſt of all!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Why, then 'tis no Diuorce, Doctor, if ſhee conſent not?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: No, if the man be frigidus, it is de parte vxoris, that we grant Libellum diuorty, in the Law.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: I, it is the ſame in Theologie.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Worſe, worſe then worſt!

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, be not vtterly diſ-heartned, wee haue yet a ſmall relike of hope left, as neare as our comfort is blowne out. Clerimont, produce your brace of Knights. What was that, Maſter Parſon, you told me in errore qualitatis e'ne now? Dauphine, whiſper the Bride, that ſhe carry it as if ſhe were guiltie, and aſham'd.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Mary Sir, in errore qualitatis (which Maſter Doctor did forbeare to vrge) if ſhe be found corupta, that is, vitiated or broken vp, that was pro virgine deſponſa, eſpous'd for a Maid—

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What then, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: It doth dirimere contractum, and irritum reddere too.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: If this bee true, wee are happy againe, Sir, once more. Here are an honourable brace of Knights, that ſhall affirme ſo much.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Pardon vs, good Maſter Clerimont.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: You ſhall excuſe vs, Maſter Clerimont.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Nay, you muſt make it good now, Knights, there is no remedie, I'll eate no words for you, nor no men: you know you ſpoke it to me?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Is this Gentleman-like-like, Sir?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Iack Daw, hee's worſe then Sir Amorous: fiercer a great deale. Sir Amorous, beware, there bee tenne Dawes in this Clerimont.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: I'll confeſſe it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Will you, Sir Amorous? will you wound reputation?

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: I am reſolu'd.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: So ſhould you be too, Iack Daw: what ſhould keep you off? ſhee is but a woman, and in diſgrace. Hee'll bee glad on't.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Will he? I thought he would ha 'beene angry.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: You will diſpatch, Knights, it muſt bee done, yfaith.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Why, an' it muſt it ſhall, Sir, they ſay. They'll ne're goe backe. Doe not tempt his patience.

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: It is true indeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: Yes, I aſſure you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What is true Gentlemen? what doe you aſſure me?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: That we haue knowne your Bride, Sir—

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: In good faſhion. Shee was our Miſtris, or ſo—

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Nay, you muſt bee plaine, Knights, as you were to mee.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: I, the queſtion is, if you haue carnaliter, or no.

sp.speaker: La-F.
sp.p: Carnaliter? what elſe, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: It is enough: a plaine nullitie.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I am vn-done, I am vn-done!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O, let me worſhip and adore you, Gentlemen!

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: I am vndone!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Yes, to my hand, I thanke theſe Knights: Maſter Parſon, let me thanke you otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: And, ha' they confeſs'd?

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: Now out vpon 'hem, Informers!

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: You ſee, what creatures you may beſtow your fauours on, Madames.

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: I would except againſt 'hem as beaten Knights, Wench, and not good Witneſſes in Law.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ot.
sp.p: Poore Gentlewoman, how ſhe takes it!

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Be comforted, Moroſe, I loue you the better for't.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: So doe I, I proteſt.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: But Gentlemen, you haue not knowne her, ſince matrimonium?

sp.speaker: Daw.
sp.p: Not to day, Maſter Doctor.

sp.speaker: La F.
sp.p: No, Sir, not to day.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Why, then I ſay, for any act before, the matrimonium is good and perfect: vnleſſe, the worſhipfull Bridegroome did preciſely, before witneſſe demand, if ſhee were virgo ante nuptias.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: No, that he did not, I aſſure you, Maſter Doctor.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: If he cannot proue that, it is ratum coniugium, notwithſtanding the premiſes. And they doe no way impedire. And this is my Sentence, this I pronounce.

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: I am of Maſter Doctors reſolution too, Sir: if you made not that demand, ante nuptias.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O my heart! wilt thou breake? wilt thou breake? this is worſt of all worſt worſts! that Hell could haue deuis'd! Marry a Whore! and ſo much noiſe!

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Come, I ſee now plaine confederacie in this Doctor, and this Parſon, to abuſe a Gentleman. You ſtudie his affliction. I pray' bee gone companions. And Gentlemen, I begin to ſuſpect you for hauing parts with 'hem. Sir, will it pleaſe you heare me?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O, doe not talke to me, take not from me the pleaſure of dying in ſilence, Nephew.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Sir, I muſt ſpeake to you. I haue beene long your poore deſpis'd Kinſ-man, and many a hard thought has ſtrength'ned you againſt me: but now it ſhall appeare if either I loue you or your peace, and preferre them to all the World beſide. I will not be long or grieuous to you, Sir. If I free you of this vnhappy match abſolutely, and inſtantly after all this trouble, and almoſt in your deſpaire, now—

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: (It cannot be.)

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p:
Sir, that you bee neuer troubled with a murmure
of it more, what ſhall I hope for, or deſerue of you?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O, what thou wilt, Nephew! thou ſhalt deſerue me, and haue me.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Shall I haue your fauour perfect to mee, and loue hereafter?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: That, and any thing beſide. Make thine owne conditions. My whole eſtate is thine. Manage it, I will become thy Ward.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, I will not be ſo vnreaſonable.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Will Sir Dauphine be mine enemie too?

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: You know, I haue beene a long Suter to you, Vncle, that out of your eſtate, which is fifteen hundred a yeere, you would allow me but fiue hundred during life, and aſſure the reſt vpon mee after: to which I haue often, by my ſelfe and friends tendred you a writing to ſigne, which you would neuer conſent, or incline too. If you pleaſe to effect it now—

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt haue it, Nephew. I will doe it, and more.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: If I quit you not preſently? and for-euer of this cumber, you ſhall haue power inſtantly, afore all theſe, to reuoke your act, and I will become, whoſe Slaue you will giue me to, for-euer.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Where is the Writing? I will ſeale to it, that, or to a Blanke, and write thine owne conditions.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: O me, moſt vnfortunate wretched Gentlewoman!

sp.speaker: Hau.
sp.p: Will Sir Dauphine doe this?

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.p: Good Sir, haue ſome compaſſion on me.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O, my Nephew knowes you belike: away Crocodile.

sp.speaker: Cen.
sp.p: He do's it not ſure, without good ground.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Here, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Come Nephew: giue me the Pen. I will ſubſcribe to any thing, and ſeale to what thou wilt, for my deliuerance. Thou art my reſtorer. Here, I deliuer it thee as my Deed. If there bee a word in it lacking, or writ with falſe Orthographie, I proteſt before—I will not take the aduantage.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p:
Then here is your releaſe,
〈…〉
Sir: you haue marryed a Boy: a Gentlemans ſonne, that I haue brought vp this halfe yeere, at my great charges, and for this compoſition, which I haue now made with you. What ſay you, Maſter Doctor? this is iuſtum impedimentum, I hope, error perſonae?

sp.speaker: Ott.
sp.p: Yes Sir, in primo gradu.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: He puls off their beards, and aiſguiſe. I thanke you, good Doctor Cutberd, and Parſon Otter. You are beholden to 'hem, Sir, that haue taken this paines for you: and my friend, Maſter Tru-wit, who enabled 'hem for the buſineſſe. Now you may goe in and reſt, be as priuate as you will, Sir. I'll not trouble you, till you trouble me with your Funerall, which I care not how ſoone it come. Cutberd, I'll make your Leaſe good. Thanke me not, but with your legge, Cutberd. And Tom Otter, your Princeſſe ſhall be reconcil'd to you. How now, Gentlemen! doe you looke at me?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: A Boy.

sp.speaker: Daup.
sp.p: Yes, Miſtris Epicoene.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p:
Well, Dauphine, you haue lurch'd your friends of the better halfe of the Garland, by concealing this part of the plot: but much good doe it thee, thou deſeru'ſt it, Lad. And Clerimont, for thy vnexpected bringing in theſe two to confeſſion, weare my part of it freely. Nay, Sir Daw, and Sir La-Foole, you ſee the Gentlewoman that has done you the fauours! we are all thankfull to you, and ſo ſhould the woman-kind here, ſpecially for lying on her, though not with her! You meant ſo, I am ſure? But, that wee haue ſtuck it vpon you to day, in your owne imagin'd perſons, and ſo lately; this Amazon, the Champion of the ſexe, ſhould beat you now thriftily, for the common ſlanders, which Ladies receiue from ſuch Cuckowes, as you are. You are they, that when no merit or fortune can make you hope to enioy their bodies, will yet lye with their reputations, and make their fame ſuffer. Away you common Moths of theſe, and all Ladies honours, Goe, trauaile to make legges and faces,
and come home with ſome new matter to be laught at: you deſerue to liue in an Ayre as corrupted, as that wherewith you feed rumour. Madames, you are mute, vpon this new Metamorphoſis! but here ſtands ſhe, that has vindicated your fames. Take heed of ſuch inſectae hereafter. And let it not trouble you that you haue diſcouer'd any Myſteries to this yong Gentleman. He is (a'moſt) of yeeres, and will make a good Viſitant within this twelue-month. In the meane time, wee'l all vndertake for his ſecrecie, that can ſpeake ſo well of his ſilence. Spectators, if you like this Comoedie, riſe cheerfully, and now Moroſe is gone in, clap your hands. It may bee, that noyſe will cure him, at leaſt pleaſe him.
